Name: The Mike
Review Title: Don't by a more expensive one. Get this!
Review Text: I literally (and I mean that in the actual definition of the word) just opened it up and set my portable monitor on it (Asus MB169+) and it works perfectly. I bought a couple other (more expensive) stands which were nice, but I didn't feel like they were sturdy enough for my monitor. This is one is very sturdy and folds up nicely for portability.

Name: DAOWAce
Review Text: Bought this to use with my Galaxy Tab A.If you're using it solely as a stand to watch and not interact with, it's fine.  Very cheap way to just use as a mini-TV basically.If you're actually interacting with the tablet, you're in for a very frustrating time.  This was my use-case.It is not sturdy.  Very lightweight.  Can't extend the legs wide enough to provide more support.It can fall over if you press the sides of the tablet. (flips backwards)It constantly moves when interacting with the screen.Want to quickly wipe down the screen to clean off fingerprints? Hah! Your tablet will be on the floor, even if you try to hold it.I couldn't even be bothered to return it and just gave it away.  Replaced it with one of those full cases that has a stand built into it.Also, the non-slip material they're using on the bottom has a smell to it and will outgas for a while, along with get on whatever touches it.

Name: KCWM
Review Title: Not as good as the other, same-style stand we use, but it works.
Review Text: After purchasing a similar stand from a brand and it working without any issues, and having good experiences with the Amazon Basics brand, I bought this as a Christmas stocking stuffer for my kid. Unfortunately, it did not hold up nearly as well as the other.The gripping material on the bottom came undone within the first week. Without it, the stand is more prone to being moved. The adhesive used is weak and there's not a lot of plastic on the bottom to attach it to. It comes loose almost every time we use it. An iPad Mini is primarily used in it, so it's not like a heavier iPad or table is being used. My kid doesn't like "the dinky stand".If I had to do it over, I'd spend a little more and get another stand.

Name: MJTop Contributor: Pets
Review Title: A couple minor flaws but overall a very good universal tablet stand.
Review Text: From many of the pictures I saw previously posted of this stand, I thought I might be stuck with the middle arm rest extending above a smaller tablet and looking unsightly.That turned out not to be the case with my small 7" tablet at the angle I like it to be tilted at while sitting at my desk. As you can see in the pictures, it can be adjusted just barely low enough to not show the middle support above my tablet (Nexus 7).I was almost ready to just go out and buy a small and cheap 99Â¢ picture frame stand but I'm glad I opted for this stand that was made for the task at hand. Not only does it have rubber on the inside of the arms where the tablet rests but it also has rubber on the bottom to help prevent it from easily sliding around your desk.A couple of things I would consider a negative is 1) at times when I was moving the legs and adjusting the stand it almost felt like I had to use so much force that something was going to break, and 2) If you want to rest the tablet on the stand in portrait mode with the webcam at the top and your charging port is on the bottom, you aren't going to be able to have it plugged into power at the same time as the legs only keep it 3/8" off the desk surface which isn't enough room for your typical MicroUSB, USB Type-C or Lightning cord to fit (see picture).

Name: Michael St James
Review Title: Good for 7 and 10-inch tablets, in or out of cases.
Review Text: This is a clever device with flawless engineering. Yes, it could be made of titanium or aluminum, but unless you plan on throwing it into the primate cage at the zoo, the plastic seems properly reinforced and strong enough for its intended purpose. My interest was to find a compact vertical orientation standing device to use with both small and large tablets, since we have a Kindle Keyboard, a PaperWhite and an original Fire as well as a Google Nexus 7 and a couple of Nexus 10s. This stand works just fine for horizontal orientation as well, but I never use mine that way.This device scores in the 10-ring for all my devices, both in and out of the cases. I only take mine out of the cases to change to another or for cleaning. The horizontal arms have three detents. I used the widest detent for the Nexus 10, and the middle detent for all other smaller devices. The narrowest detent is the closed (folded up) position. I didn't count the detents on the vertical arm where it joins the base (many), but it ratchets to positions that would satisfy any conceivable need. The vertical arm is divided in half by a joint with four detents allowing for the adjustment of the flat upper part of the arm so you can have it rest flush on the back of your device.I have added pictures of Nexus 7 and 10 and for Kindle Fire in the stand. I initially adjusted the arm for the larger tablet, and didn't bother to change it for the smaller devices, and it worked fine that way. (Edit note: Though all 6 pics seemed to UL OK, I see that Amazon is only displaying 3 of the 6. Oh, well.)I put my Galaxy Note 2 in it (vertically) just to check the fit, and it's fine! I hadn't thought of that until I received my stands. I'm ordering a third one tonight so I can keep on my desk for the phone, instead of just laying it flat.Both of the horizontal arms have a soft, tacky black anti-skid insert over in the entire length of their bottoms. Very effective. This same material is applied on the outside surface of the resting grooves cut into the top of the arms. Once again, very effective. The flat articulating surface of the upper half of the vertical arm has this same material applied to it.I used all of the devices in the stand, swiping vigorously horizontally and vertically, and the devices always remained secure in the stand, and did not slide on the surface of the counter.I bought two of these, one for my wife.Five stars because I can't find one thing to complain about.

Name: Coffeelover
Review Text: Great affordable stand.  Helped me turn my new IPad Air 2 and blue tooth keyboard into a mini "lap top." I have found the various positions that you can adjust for the stand to be quite a nice fit for my needs.  I really like that you can bend the upper portion of the vertical support to get the best angle for your use.  It also folds back up into a nice small size, making it very portable.

Name: Joey
Review Text: After reading all of the great reviews I was very eager to receive and use this product. I am so confused because almost all the feedback is positive, so maybe my product is defective?? All it takes is the lightest tap on my iPad to cause the entire stand(and with it, the iPad) to fall over. Matter of fact, I can't even swipe the bottom to unlock my iPad without it toppling over let alone open any apps with a light tap of my finger! I am upset because I am always satisfied with AmazonBasics product lines, however this stand is virtually unusable. Hopefully it's just a defective stand, so I will return it for a replacement and update this review accordingly.

Name: Peter
Review Text: This item works. It's a straightforward and uncomplicated item. I use it to prop up my iPad Air with a slim case. This item holds the tablet very securely in both portrait and landscape mode. The stand collapses into a small and portable size that easily fits into my man bag.I tried to use this with my iPad Pro 12.9, and it wasn't great. In landscape mode, the stand held the tablet, but it was a little shaky. In portrait mode, the tablet was just too top heavy. Since I use the Pro tablet mostly in portrait mode, this stand wasn't suitable. However, I don't fault the stand, since it's not designed for the larger tablets. I just wanted to tell other people my experience in case they're curious about using it with the iPad Pro.

Name: John Williamson
Review Title: Swiss Army Knife of Tablet Travel Stands: It's a winner
Review Text: This blackÂ AmazonBasics Portable Fold-Up Travel Stand  Â is a truly versatile device.  It's compact and quite well engineered, and is the perfect portable accompaniment for the Kindle Fire, the legacy Kindle e-book readers, the new iPad or iPad 2, the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 and probably many more.  In my case, I have a Kindle Fire and a Kindle 2, so interchangeability between devices is not only important, but also essential. For those wishing for the quick points, here they arePros:* Can be quickly and easily adjusted into a wide variety of viewing angles* Very sturdy construction; doesn't feel junky or cheap* Quite convenient; folds up to 7 x 1 x 1 inches for good portability* Soft foam-padded surfaces on bottom prevent sliding; won't scratch furniture* Padded grips where the tablet or e-reader sits; keeps device in place; no scratching* Foam padded back support; keeps tablet stable and won't scratch the case* Good IKEA-style simple Quick Start instruction sheet in multiple languages* Frustration-Free Packaging; no irritating plastic clamshell to open when receivedCons:* Very minor point: most devices can't be charged in the vertical (portrait) mode; there's no space for most cable connectorsIn Use:I had picked up theÂ AmazonBasics Mini Travel Stand  Â earlier, and at barely over two inches long have found it excellent for quick field use and extreme portability. Small and very compact, it folds up and snaps shut so that it can put in your pocket (or purse) without taking up much room. That one is good for stable, flat surface locations where there isn't too much activity going on, and I've found it excellent with my Kindle 2 with it's 6-inch display when it's removed from its leather cover. The newer Kindle Touch or any of the newer versions with the 6-inch E Ink display would have no problems with the Mini Travel Stand.At 7 x 1 x 1 inches, the newerÂ AmazonBasics Portable Fold-Up Travel Stand  Â may lack the compactness of the Mini version, but when it comes to outright versatility, this is where it really shines.  To begin with, its range of adjustments is exceptionally good, and I did not have to remove theÂ Marware Vibe Case Cover  Â from my Kindle Fire, nor the leather cover from my Kindle 2, in order to use it with this stand.  It can be quickly changed in a wide array of positions for viewing, in either the horizontal (landscape) or vertical (portrait) position.  And using it with the Kindle Fire, I found that it wasn't moving all over the place when used with a stylus.The foam padding has been placed in all of the crucial areas where it may be needed.  The foam-padded surfaces on bottom of the feet prevent sliding, even when being used on a flat surface with a stylus, and it won't scratch your furniture.  The adjustable foam-padded back support helps keeps tablet stable in use, and the padded grips where the tablet or e-reader sits add to the stability.  This one is designed where it won't scratch the case.Note that there are some other brands, such as theÂ Arkon Portable Fold-Up Stand  , that may offer a similar design and features as this one, but I personally trust the AmazonBasics products that I've found here as they have a decent guarantee, and based on my experience with one defective item, I do like their responsiveness when things go wrong.Bottom Line:It didn't take me long to figure out that this AmazonBasics Portable Fold-Up Travel Stand would be the default choice for use with my Kindle Fire, and the Mini Travel Stand would be the one for my Kindle 2.  Each one has its good points, as you can see here, but that's a subjective choice, so take for what it's worth to you.  Admittedly if I had to pick just one I would go with the newer Fold-Up Travel Stand simply because of its overall usefulness and functionality.This AmazonBasics Portable Fold-Up Travel Stand has true Swiss Army knife versatility, and I have no problems recommending this as an excellent product at a very good price.6/8/2012

Name: V. Gaines
Review Text: After seeing this pop up on a weekly deal email, I thought it might just be the solution I was looking for to help with an external monitor that I travel with. I have an ASUS portable USB external monitor that I use as a second monitor with my laptop that came with a very lame "stand" of sorts. The case that you store it in can somehow be contorted to act as a stand...which I have never successfully got to work. I end up leaning it on lamps and such at hotels while traveling. But this little stand worked great! Fully adjustable to fit whatever circumstances, and cushioned to keep the screen from sliding around. It folds up to about 7" long by 1" tall and 1" wide...which fits perfectly in my backpack. I know it was intended for iPads and such...and I can see where that would work great too, but if anyone has the same problem I had with a travel monitor...this is THE solution for it!

Name: GOLDENDUDE
Review Title: Good looking build but no cigar.
Review Text: Bought this for my work tablet. The stand by looking on Amazon before I bought it looked sturdy,but when I received  it isn't. Only configuration that holds the tablet  is the picture  I took. The places it has moving parts do just that they move there's no way to lock it to any position. You put the slightest pressure  on table and the stand fails to hold its position.  I'll  use it in the 1 position that works . But I'm not expecting  it to last to long due to the moveablilty of the parts.

Name: The Night King
Review Title: Yes, it can hold the iPad Pro 12.9
Review Text: this adjustable stand can easily hold the new (2018) iPad Pro in both landscape and portrait mode. I absolutely love how compact it is when you close it up. only had a chance to play with it for a week. So far, so good. Time will tell how durable it will be long term. It seems like it will last a while. Even if it doesn't, it's a cheap product to replace it needed.

Name: kapran
Review Title: Why the stand is just OK and NOT 5 Stars
Review Text: The stand arrived today on time and it's certainly on budget. As usual the packaging was the first thing I didn't like because I hate packaging that is not user friendly when I'm trying to get it open without damaging the box or bag, or bubble pack. It came in a compact box and was undamaged. What it lacks is the notching is too small to hold a tablet inside a case, and my case is vinyl and somewhat compact and thin. Whoever designed this didn't have the forethought to even test drive it with "Amazon's Choice" of commonly used tablet cases and then say how well it fits so many models. Well not so fast. Who uses a tablet most? Well that's kids for sure and those should and normally do have a kids case most of the time but those are big and bulky and I might not expect that to fit a regular stand but I'm an ADULT. And who doesn't want a slimline case and compatible stand so you can have it vertical or horizontal INSIDE THE CASE? They didn't even give it any thought whatsoever and say "well we can't speak to that", well you should have because I sure would have and I'm not a product designer, engineer, or tester I'm a consumer and we have the expectation that products will be evaluated in a variety of use cases scenarios. And it at least adjusts quite easily to many positions, folds up well - nice and compact, lightweight and the price was right. But it was easily within the potential of 5 stars if anyone with a brain had even spent 5 minutes thinking about it.

Name: Sheryl
Review Text: I bought this to use to prop my kindle on when I want to read at the kitchen table. I have a kindle oasis in one of Amazonâ€™s â€œleatherâ€ cases that opens like a book and auto turns on the kindle when opened. This stand works perfectly for it even while itâ€™s in its case. I just have to tilt the tall part of the stand forward a bit to accommodate the smaller size of the kindle and I can adjust the legs to a variety of settings too get the kindle to sit at whatever angle I want it at. Itâ€™s easy to collapse and open too. I havenâ€™t tried to use it with my ipad yet but I donâ€™t need to because my iPad is in a keyboard case that opens like a laptop, so I canâ€™t speak to how it works with that. But if you want something for your actual kindle, I can say this works well, even with the small Oasis.

Name: ccsteveTop Contributor: Pets
Review Text: I was looking for a small adjustable tablet stand for reading the online newspaper in the mornings. I had been using my husband's large padded one that works great in his lap while watching tv, but I needed one for tabletop use while having my morning coffee. I like this primarily because it folds down into a small size (about 2" x 5") when not in use so that I can put it away out of sight. It has two legs which form the stand and they can be adjusted in width to accommodate any size tablet or phone. And the single upright piece that forms the back can be bent to several positions depending how upright you wish your tablet or phone to be. Overall, a great little device for the purpose.

Name: Jeffrey DanielsTop Contributor: BBQ Styles
Review Title: Finally, I can read my morning paper!
Review Text: Sheesh. I know the world is filled with TV and movie watching over all these mobile devices, but some of us still like to read normal way. And I'm one of the some.I like to e-read my morning paper with breakfast. That means I need my Kindle to stand upright. Alas, the new cases all seem to be great with horizontal balance but a wobble nightmare vertically. As you can see in the first picture, I have to use the charge cable just to stabilize the Kindle.BUT! Here comes this nifty - and incredibly economical - tablet stand that easily and expertly holds my Kindle upright. No wobble! Woo Hoo!I've tested it with pressing the on/off and volume buttons as well as swiping and selecting on screen. Firm and vibration free. The pads on the "feet" of the stand nicely "grab" the table, creating the stability and firmness needed for a nightmare free experience.This is a great, great (let's give it one more), great find for me and for anyone looking for a stable way to seat your tablet (in this case a Kindle Fire). Buy one. Heck, buy two. Christmas is coming and you know someone who could use one!

Name: Int93
Review Title: Works great for an external monitor!
Review Text: I got this originally for an iPad (4th Gen), which it worked great. I found another iPad stand that was super slim and light and worked well enough for me so I ended up giving this to my Wife for her iPad mini. But then I ended up purchasing a portable touch screen monitor and I asked her if I could switch her out for my other one for a week and see if it worked out and she could tell me which one she liked better since I would end up buying one of the 2 iPad stands again if it ends up working for my monitor. She actually likes this one better and felt it more stable, which I would agree it is overall more stable.It ended up working perfectly for my monitor. I like to put it in vertical orientation often and this actually works surprisingly well. It is the best option I have found to be able to bring to and from school and to also fit on a lap desk that I use since I change rooms a lot and I can just pick up everything in one go. When picking up and going the screen can topple over, but that's an extreme case, for normal usage I go back and forth between my monitors and touch the screen a lot and it has never toppled or failed me when I prop it up in the way in the picture. I can even quickly switch it to horizontal orientation quickly and easily.I bough some adhesive backed foam to add to the front edge as I felt like it was rubbing the back of my monitor slightly. Also after some use with the monitor the adhesive pads that already came attached where you set the iPad in started to get smooshed and come apart a little, so if you have something that is wide that may be something to expect. I just took them off and added a full layer of adhesive pad instead of the little bit that was just on the front side of the grooves. I pack this up and take it with me to and from school everyday, love it.

Name: Gary L. Herstein
Review Title: When you get tired of holding your tablet
Review Text: I'd previously been repurposing a plate-holder to try and keep my (Samsung 9") tablet up. That didn't last.This is sturdy, flexible, and compact, all the things I require (esp. if we get past the pandemic & I can travel again.) Props to the designers and engineers who made it, this does the job it says it is supposed to do, a rare enough quality these days that I am really excited to see it made real. It easily accommodates my Samsung in either the vertical or horizontal position. In either position, it is solid enough to not fall over when I use the touch screen. But if I'm using the blue-tooth keyboard, I can set it to whatever angle does not wash out the screen with ambient light.I've only tested it on MY tablet, so obviously your mileage may vary. But it is clearly adaptable to larger and smaller devices than my own.

Name: ATLBrysco
Review Title: The most basic design is usually the most elegant.
Review Text: EXCELLENT stand for my 7" tablet. This is utilized for a low-end tablet that really does little more than function as a digital photo frame on my nightstand. However, because the table was low-end the cheap case for it doesn't keep it propped up because it's too flimsy and slides all over a wooden surface.This stand is perfect - lightweight, yet sturdy, I like the fact that it has "grippy" material all over to not only help keep the tablet in place, but allows the stand to not slide across the surface of the nightstand. Further, because the design is basic and demure, it doesn't detract focus away from the tablet as it rotates through images.There are many tablet stands on here that are ridiculous in cost - some up to $40+. This does the job beautifully, is inexpensive and is exactly what I wanted. Good job, AmazonBasics!

Name: Jet Builder
Review Title: An Impulse Buy, But One I'm Glad I Made!
Review Text: I had looked for a cover for my Kindle Oasis that could serve as a stand as well.  I didn't find anything that struck my fancy, but this was one of the suggested products when I was looking for the Kindle covers (I bought the MoKo Case and have had a love hate relationship with it).  For the price I was willing to give the stand a try and I'm glad I did.  The design is compact; it can hold my Kindle Oasis securely in any orientation on almost any surface.  It folds down to a size similar to an eyeglass case.  It's very lightweight.  It adjusts to multiple different positions allowing you to use it with other small tablets or even your smart phone.  I use this stand every day with my Kindle and I love how the rubberized surface of the legs grip countertops.  The notches in the legs that hold the lower edge of my Kindle also have that same rubberized surface.  As does the adjustable upstanding arm that supports the rear.  All I can say is that I can't imagine that I would have had the same positive experience with my Kindle without this cool little device!UPDATE - 11 JUNE, 2020.Well, I've had this little device for over a year.  I use it several times a day to hold my Kindle while i read.  Other than being slightly looser than when i first received it there hasn't been any degradation.  I can't tell you how pleased I've been with this purchase.  If I were to lose it or if it broke I would definitely replace it wit the same thing.  There's not a lot of items that I can say that about.  Great job, Amazon!

Name: D. White
Review Title: Should be your #1 item on school supply list
Review Text: I brought this as a stand for my kindergartener's ipad for virtual learning. This may be the most indestructible thing currently made. It's multi positional, allowing her to adjust to her line of sight and be able to get a perfect  angle on her camera. Its non-skid grip pads makes sure that the base does not move and there are also pads are on the notch where the tablet rests, so that will not budge either, even when her desk is bumped by her siblings. No need to take bulky cases off, it will fit with a bulky case!! It folds and closes small enough to fit in her pencil case, which is awesome for when she does go in for face to face testing. The schools should buy this in bulk for the students instead of spending the extra $$ on cases with integrated stands that either don't fold to an ideal level to capture the student on camera or rip/ break/tear after 2 months of DAILY 8-10 hour use. If you can, buy more and gift to other kids!!!

Name: JaneDoe966Top Contributor: Pets
Review Title: An excellent addition for my Samsung Tab A 10.1.
Review Text: In addition to the two cases I bought for my tablet, I also bought two stands (this and a pillow stand that has not yet arrived.), Â¹not sure which options would be best. I am very happy with my case, but because the tablet is rectangular and much taller than it is wide, using the built-in stand within the case, is not practical for how I use it (on my lap, which is under a comforter). So I am very glad I got this Amazon Basics stand as well. It is very sturdy, stable, highly adjustable, and can be used on both hard AND soft surfaces. The best part, is that I don't even need to take my tablet out of it's case to use while it's on this stand. The stand folds up to stored wherever you wish. I store mine in a padded bag I have for my tablet. I would imagine you really could use this stand for all sorts of tablets and phones because of you can adjust so many things about it (tilt, width, etc.).

Name: Carl L.
Review Title: Very useful for holding a Kindle, once you know how to open it.
Review Text: When I received this item, I thought it was defective.  I could open one of the legs, but the other was quite resistant.  I thought I would break it if I tried any harder, and requested a replacement.  Amazon sent one with no quibbling, and did not ask me to return the original.  Lo and behold, when the replacement arrived, it was also hard to open one leg.  This time I pulled harder, and it opened.  Subsequent to that first time, it opened more easily.  It holds a Kindle at a good angle for reading when you are sitting at a table or desk, and folds up small so you can easily transport or store it when not in use.After my success with the replacement, I tried the original and with my new knowledge to tug harder, it works too.  I feel a little guilty that I got a second one free, but that was not intentional.

Name: DEC
Review Title: OK for the price.  I little light but that is commensurate with the low price.
Review Text: It's OK for the price since it is cheap.  IT is a fairly lightweight bit of plastic though.  After - check out the weight at 3.2 oz.  Very light.The one I got was prtty much fozen on one side initially.  I had to use a fair amount of force to move one side the first time.  After that it was like the plastic on the small nubs that click along got ronuded off a bit and it was therewfter easier.  The adjustments are somewhat granular but they will suffice for now.  I doubt it will see other than occasional use from me.  I got it to use with a fire HD10 i just bought and it will just work for that although I feel the HD10 is pushing the envelope for the size device this handles.  It does fold up very nice and compact so if portability is your desire this should be great.  I only use my fire at home so that is of limited value to me.  If you want something heavy for stability this is not it.  IF I used a stand with the HD10 often I would keep looking and get something heavier.  For my occasional to seldom use it will just do for now.

Name: KellyTop Contributor: Pets
Review Title: Easy to Move.. sometimes too easy
Review Text: GOOD:+The triangular shape and low profile of this base allows it to fit into corners & other tight spots.+You can swivel the arm up to any angle, to adjust your tablet to whatever viewing angle you want.+The notches are big enough that you can still fit the tablet in there with a cover on.NOT GREAT:-The back arm is really easy to move. Tapping the tablet screen too hard is enough to push the arm back into a lower position.Overall I'm happy with this stand, though I wish the back arm were just a little more stiff.

Name: Sarah
Review Text: Omg. I never thought I could be so excited for such a little/inexpensive thing, but I absolutely adore this.  A few months ago I invested in a 15.6 inch portable monitor to make working from home easier on my laptop.  The monitor came with a carrying case which also doubled as its stand.  It was fine, but not great.  The case was bulky on my tiny desk and easy to knock over or would sometimes just fall down.I saw this little guy and though he was recommended for tablets, figured I'd give it a shot.  This takes up much less space and is sturdy enough to hold the monitor well.  It also has non-slip grip  on the bottom (not fool-proof of course, but much better than the previous stand).  All in all super happy with this small, yet amazingly effective purchase.

Name: Debbie L O'Halloran
Review Text: During the pandemic I adopted a dog. One of the adoption requirements is that all dogs adopted from the rescue have a basic training course. At the time all training sessions through the rescue were done by Zoom. Rather than use my laptop, I decided to use my iPad. The iPad case that can hold the tablet didnâ€™t allow for the best angle to viewand participate in the training. I found this inexpensive Amazon tablet holder and it works great! It has multi angles to place the tablet securely. It worked much better than the case. You can also use it with a bluetooth keyboard so you can use your tablet like a laptop. The best thing is it folds up so you can easily take it with you. I love this nest little gAdget!

Name: SEICORP
Review Title: WORKS LIKE A CHAMP AND TAKES MINIMAL ROOM TO STORE
Review Text: Bought this for my wife for her Kindle Paper White. Her Kindle is almost always in her hand wherever she goes. At the dinner table she was using one hand to hold up the Kindle for proper reading angle and the other hand for eating. It always looked so uncomfortable I looked online for a device to hold it for her. YIKES. There were so many models, versions, types, styles, etc. my mind went numb trying to figure out which one would be the one she would like best, she is very picky and ordering anything for her is always a crap-shoot! I just thought this particular model was going to be ok and got it. When she first saw it, she was upset and asked what she was to do with another gadget she really didn't need. She grudgingly started using it and now she will not even let me use it for my Kindle when we eat together. She loves it. It folds up into almost nothing and stores anywhere. It is quick to set up and has a wide range of adjustment to give just the right viewing angle. Great simple product that actually works!

Name: VickiC
Review Title: Works great with thick, kiddy-style ipad protective case!
Review Text: Disliked: Operator error... HA!  I thought I was breaking it when I started to open the bracket up and it was so hard so I thought there was a trick to it. But then I saw the instruction manual, which simply showed moving the legs in the form I was trying. So I more boldly pressed and heard a racheting sound to indicate I was just needing to overcome little security spots. And it is because of that racheting action that it HOLDS so STURDILY, which is definitely one of its << BEST FEATURES!My kiddy-style protector makes most holders unusable simply for form factor -- it simply does not FIT in the GROOVES intended for thinner mini ipad. Not only do these frooves FIT the fatter body well, but it will hold in STURDY FASHION in a VARIETY of POSITIONS needed for various functions/apps -- wide or tall.PERFECT!! THANK YOU!  BTW packaged in impeccable box.

Name: Tyler Ashton
Review Title: NOTE: This does not have any way to tighten the stand. However,
Review Text: First of all for 12$ this is a great little stand. It's compact and you can take it with you easily. It's easy to pop open and my ipad fits in it. I did have to be crafty with my case ON but I made it work. It works a lot better with a case off unless you have a silicone case. It's plastic, but sturdy.If you draw the only qualm is if you put too much pressure it will move positions because there's no way to lock it in place. But I got it to work just fine. Just don't push down too hard. This is more so made for like if you want to set your tablet up and watch something or to make quick notes or just small stuff like that. It does work for me but I can see that some might find that it doesn't lock annoying.Over all I love this little thing. It will do for now and it's a great option if you're strapped for cash.

Name: B. Hackman
Review Text: This stand is so well designed I bought and extra one!  This stand solves the tipping or collapsing problem you get with the folio cases when you use a stylus.  The problem with Folio cases is you can adjust the angle and normally it will stay where you put it.  The minute you use a stylus on the Folio Case on the upper 50% of the display it could lift the bottom of the tablet out of the groves and your tablet could collapse.This stand is not only sturdy - it will hold your tablet in Landscape or Portrait position securely.  In fact I do not even take my tablet out of the Folio Case when I use it.  The groves in the stand can hold the thinnest tablet or most cases with the tablet in the case!  It is very portable folding to 1 inch by 7 inch by 1 1/4 inch.  It is well padded to protect your tablet.  Some people who have reviewed this stand complained that they can not charge the unit when in Portrait mode.  I know my Amazon Fire HDX 8.9" has auto rotation and charges perfectly in Portrait mode just turn it upside down..  Please make sure you have rotation turned on. For those of you who like to use your tablet at lunch or when having a cup of coffee - this stand elevates your tablet 3/4 to 1 inch above the surface (So if you have a spill, the stand will allow your spill to go under the stand - NOT on your tablet!)  That is a small price to pay for a unit that does so much.Conclusion - This is the best designed most cost effective stand offered today at an extremely reasonable price.  Buy with confidence - This stand is a winner!  I hope this helps you.

Name: Curtis
Review Text: I'm very impressed by this stand. First off, it's a fairly simple and compact design, the main arm that holds the tablet upright has two points of articulation, both of which are joints with an interlocking teeth design. This does mean that it has slightly fewer positions than some of the aluminum tension lock stands, but it is very sturdy and I've been able to get any angle that I could reasonably need. The two feet each have 3 positions: folded against each other, spaced slightly apart such that you could fit a phone on in vertically, and spaced farther apart for tablet use. The feet have notches to accommodate your device, and the nothces, the arm, and the bottom of the feet have this black rubber-foam stuff that does an excellent job of keeping everything in place- nothing is going to move unless you want it to.All of my devices fit in this even with their cases on, and even with the larger cases- I have my Samsung Tab S3 9.7 inch in a leather case that more than doubles its thickness, and the stand still works perfectly. I really can't think of anything to complain about, other than I might want one made out of a slightly heavier material, but the black plastic is fairly heavy duty, and travels well due to it's light weight

Name: Carlos
Review Title: I wouldnâ€™t place this at edge of bed or couch
Review Text: Temporarily needed this for my 2018 iPad Pro 12.9 and it got the job done but with caution. I wanted to use it to prop up the iPad 12.9 while I lay in bed and on the couch, it works but I wouldnâ€™t want to leave it at the edge of the bed or couch. I ended up getting a Fohloy adjustable grip handle thing that slapped at the back of my 12.9 that does a better job than this. I can use this for other things though like propping up frames and books for decorations. I also found the same or unbranded product a few dollar cheaper else where. I wish it was a shape of a goal post or W instead of a Y, maybe it would make it more stable for other tops not just table tops.

Name: Mycroft
Review Text: It isn't likely to wind up on the cover of Time as one of the most important inventions of the new century, but if you are tired of wrestling that slab-sided tablet which is supposed to be cute and cuddly and is more like a boat anchor, this is the goodie for you. I'm still not converted to tablet use, to me the loss of all the Desktop real estate is too great a penalty to pay, but its hard to carry a desktop to the doctors to read while your arteries harden waiting for a man who has all the time in the world and wants to make sure you don't. Folds away so you can drop it in a pocket and have it where ever you wind up wanting something written in this century.

Name: Love-Leigh Book Reviews
Review Text: I needed something to stand my iPad or phone up and this little stand has been perfect! The back adjusts so that my iPads (full size ipad) weight is evenly distributed and it is completely stable. I can even stand my phone up on it since the feet can be moved closer together. Also, the bottom has rubber on it so it doesnâ€™t move making it even more stable. Really glad I bought this, I use it pretty much daily.

Name: R. Griswold
Review Text: Have had this gadget long enough to try it out with tablets of various sizes and in various locations. I find that it does its simple job very well and is quite worthwhile. It has rubber feet and doesn't slide around. Once set for a situation, it holds its setting securely. It is adjustable and will hold phones and tablets up to 10 inch size, perhaps larger. It holds them firmly enough that you can press on touch screens and provide control inputs. I have tried unlevel and uneven surfaces, within reason, and it always worked well. I am well satisfied with this thing and would buy a second one if needed.

Name: Timothy S.
Review Text: Don't hesitate...buy this!  Better yet, buy two!I'm using this every day on my desk and on jobsites with my full sized iPad in an OtterBox Defender case (thick and heavy).It works PERFECTLY in both landscape or portrait mode.Easily adjustable for glare or weight distribution of the iPad.  Stable enough to hold iPad upright for FT calls while sitting at my desk (doesn't tip forward).Easily folds up, fits in pocket, bag, or toolbox...can be rinsed off when it gets muddy or dusty.A perfect, elegant, VERY economical, and VERY portable stand!!

Name: The Ballroom Dancer
Review Title: Sturdy, adjustable tablet holder for Amazon Fire
Review Text: Love, Love, Love this tablet holder for my Amazon Fire.  Even with a tablet cover (It winds up being about an inch thick) it holds it perfectly.  I can adjust for any angle very easily. I had an old Apple iPad with a cover that had ways to hold it horizontal or vertical and it would fall over all the time. This product works great. It doesn't interfere with the cover in any way.  Totally easy to use and it folds small so you can take it with you anywhere or it can easily fit in a drawer.  Just one other note - thought maybe I could use it to hold a big 3 ring cookbook binder, but it's too top heavy and it can't hold it properly. However, it works great for my smaller spiral bound cookbooks (tablet size).

Name: Actual Customer
Review Text: I use my Samsung Galaxy Tab S4 tablet to read my Kindle books.  But getting a good portrait orientation holder is absolutely impossible.  Even the landscape cases aren't all that good and the tablet is unsteady and slips and falls flat.  This simple stand really works.  Even with the case.  For some reason stand manufacturers never really account for cases.  They must think we walk around with naked unprotected tablets.  I'm typing this review with my tablet, in it's case, sitting on this stand.  My case alone as a stand would have slipped several times by now with my finger taps.  This stand is totally stable.  Wow.  Somebody did it right.  I may get several more.  Grezt buy!

Name: PattyTTop Contributor: Makeup
Review Title: Though she be little, she be fierce.
Review Text: When I first got this little stand, I was very skeptical of it. It's so small and plastic and just...not what I expected. BUT, I have been using it with my Samsung 8" tablet, my Kindle Fire 10", and even my phone and it works really well and super simply. There are adjustments for size and angle and it is really all I need. It holds my stuff in and out of their cases and it doesn't collapse or shift. I suppose if I paid a lot more, I could get one that has more features and is made of steel but this little stand has held up fine for months now with no issues. I like that it is so compact that I can carry it in my small cases for my tablets and pull it out when I need it. I really have no complaints,. It was cheap and it does the job very well of holding my devices up at the angle I want them whether they are horizontal or vertical. This was an excellent buy,.

Name: DeeDee Webster
Review Text: I bought this because I use my reader for textbooks.  As I am studying I have found that I can read/see the ebook better when it is propped up during writing my assignments.  I found this gadget and it was one of the less expensive ones on Amazon.  I can adjust the stand for the height of the desk and angle needed to read comfortably.  I actually bought two because sometimes I refer to two different textbooks and, therefore, I have two different readers.  Both of my readers are in protective covers and this stand holds both of them without any issues of tipping or fear of instability.

Name: The Owl Underground
Review Title: If you've got a tablet or a Kindle, you need one of these.
Review Text: This is a great stand at a great price.  It works brilliantly with both my 10-inch tablet and my Kindle Fire.  The two arms that rest on the flat surface adjust wider and narrower to accommodate Kindles and tablets in both portrait and landscape orientations. The upright arm is jointed to adjust the angle at which the tablet can be viewed -- from about a 45-degree angle to nearly perpendicular. This stand is so adjustable it could even hold an iPhone.  When not in use the stand folds up into a compact, bar shape that will fit easily in a suitcase, briefcase, messenger bag or even a purse.  Skype on your tablet?  You need one of these.  Watch TV, movies or videos on your tablet?  You need one of these.  Read ebooks on your tablet?  You need one of these.

Name: James W.
Review Text: Looked at a few stands to serve a duel purpose: 1) To be used as a desk top stand for my Galaxy Tab A and 2) to use as a portable stand when traveling.  This stand fit both those needs.  It is very sturdy and adjustable; can be adjusted to almost any angle.  It easily holds a tablet in either portrait or landscape mode.  The only downside is using a charging cable when using it to hold a device in portrait mode (whith the USB connection on the bottom).  There is not enough enough clearance for a straight (normal) USB connection; I over came this by using a right angle USB cable.

Name: TWM
Review Title: Does a Great Job of Supporting iPad for a Low Price
Review Text: The multi-articulation of this stand, together with the non-slip rubber pads on the bottom, the vertical pillar, and the rubber padding of the notches which hold the bottom end of the tablet make this stand a winner for not much money. I have two of these and both are wonderful and were delivered very swiftly via prime. There's no need to look further or spend more money.

Name: Tam N.
Review Text: I use this to prop up my 15" Microsoft Surface Book 2's clipboard section and it works as advertised. I can route the charger over one of the legs and under the charging port, although it is quite angled so I usually have the device pushed a little to the side to give the cord some slack (why am I doing all this when I could just flip the device around...). The clicks of the stand are distinctive, and work as intended. The back support is adjustable to give you the desired viewing angle. The addition of foam at the bottom of the stand is a nice touch. It folds up fairly compactly so transporting it shouldn't be an issue. It's a stand. It works. What more do you want?

Name: forkdora
Review Text: This is the first iPad stand I've bought so I can't compare it to other products, but it's exactly what I was looking for. It's made from sturdy plastic, so I'm not concerned about it breaking during travel or just during regular use. The three arms fold together to form a little compact piece about the length of my hand, so it'll be easy to pack and take on a plane. During use, the stand was secure, no wobbles, and I was easily able to adjust it to the angle I wanted.

Name: Dave Kramer
Review Title: Works great with my bulky case
Review Text: I purchased a case that simply fails as a stand - it only provides two viewing angles, and both slant upwards. This makes it hard to view when sitting in the bath (at a lower angle) or wandering around the kitchen.Rather than ditch the case (which otherwise is great), I bought this stand and it works well. I fold the cover behind the iPad, which does it make it super thick. Most stands wouldn't accommodate it without removing it from the case but this one works great. The iPad + case is a bit thick for the two notches on the V-shaped base but it still wedges in OK and seems relatively stable (more stable than when I tried standing the iPad straight up in the case alone).I may pick up another 1-2 so I can keep these where I need them around the house, and someday post-COVID I'll pack one up for travel.

Name: Vicky and Tom
Review Title: Works for a smartphone; annoying to adjust
Review Text: I should start out by saying I am using this for a phone, which is actually a hair smaller than the minimum size for the stand. That presents some issues, but the rating is for the stand overall, not phone-specific issues (although I will describe those too).Bought this to use with a phone & wireless keyboard for a superlight email/browsing setup. I originally had a tablet with a kickstand case, but when I got a smartphone I didn't want a bulky case so I got this to keep the functionality.Overall it works pretty good. You can tell it would work better with a medium-sized tablet. It does work with my 5.7" smartphone, but it has to be at its smallest/most-folded setting to fit, and the top of the back arm pokes above the screen which is a bit silly. But the feet are grippy and the adjustment mechanism is solid, and I think it would work with all but the smallest smartphones.The adjustment is actually the only drawback. The mechanism is nice and firm - so firm that I have to use both hands to re-size it. And it adjusts in notches/clicks, so getting super-fine adjustment is hard. Adjusting the angle of the tablet also could be more intuitive - the back arm pivots, but the legs also have adjustable spread, and both settings change the adjustment, so you have to monkey around a bit to get it just right.Still, very solidly built, and works with a 'phablet' phone. Also nice that the nooks that catch the bottom edge of the phone have non-stick on them, but don't stick up so far as to block access/view to the bottom edge of yer phone/tablet.TLDR: Works with smartphones but looks a bit silly. Adjusting requires taking the device off and using both hands.

Name: JDR
Review Text: I admit I purchased this holder with some reservation as many tend to be garbage that cannot hold their own weight much less a small phone. This holder turned out to be sturdy with no wobble, and capable of accommodating a classic small smartphone all the way to a large 11 inch tablet with no issues. You need to figure out the right combination of the three supports, otherwise you can encounter the problem others have. However it takes just a few seconds to figure the right combination, and once you have it it is hard to forget. Excellent product and perfect for the office desk, restaurant table, and anywhere you need to be.

Name: Eljay
Review Text: I use this for video calls using apple 8+ and for reading my kindle paperwhite. I love it. I will be buying another one because one stays on the patio, and I would like one for the craft room as well.It stands strong even when turning pages using a knuckle ( while I am eating LOL) I was having a lot of trouble on my video calls because the screen was too close to my face and I had no free hands. I used this one time and felt so relieved. I was so easy to find and hold the correct angle using the adjustable stand. YAY!! would recommend, would buy again

Name: REHi
Review Text: After reading some of the reviews, I was a little worried.  Upon arrival though, my concerns were gone.  Its a clever, small folding pieces of plastic that have lille phillips screws in the two critical hinges with little nuts on them recessed into the plastic. The feet that form the base spread into an angle that can vary. I can attest that it will adequately support a smart phone, a ipad mini and a regular ipad, all in horizontal or vertical position. Easy to stow in a pocket.Definitely recommend as a cheap, capable support system for devices mentioned.

Name: VirginiaHoosier
Review Text: Not nearly as good as the I-home stand I got from Apple several years ago but is no longer available â€” at least I have been unable to find it. The Amazon stand tends to buckle when more than gentle pressure is applied to the screen. The screws holding the pieces together tend to loosen. Naturally this is remedied by getting a small screwdriver and tightening the screws. The more they are tightened, the more stable the stand. But then it is harder to adjust. Nevertheless, given the low price and the bulky size of the alternatives, this stand is ok.

Name: Amazon Customer
Review Title: It's great!  However, it needs more clearance at the bottom.
Review Text: The stand is nice. After adjusting it, the tablet fits nicely. The one issue I had with the tablet, is there is very little clearance at the bottom. Since my tablet is a Galaxy Tab S4, the charging port was foolishly placed at the bottom by the designers of the tablet at Samsung. So in order to avoid the problem , I put my tablet upside down. The tablet is able to detect the orientation  and invert the screen. Now my charging port is on top. That is where it should have been put bythe Samsung designers.

Name: Michael Cerda
Review Text: I bought this to hold an Amazon Fire HD 10 in landscape mode. The stand is compact and easy to adjust. Use a firm steady hand to adjust. If you jerk the appendages you could break them. I find the stand very stable. You can use the screen while the tablet is on the stand. It won't tip as long as the tablet is positioned at least 30 degrees or so. The bottom edge of the tablet has to be in firmly fitted into the notches on the legs. I got this over the Fire cover because it have me more options to set the tilt angle. The last two pictures show the tablet in portrait mode. For better stability have the stand contact the tablet higher up.

Name: littlemixi
Review Text: This stand doesn't even hold it's own weight, let alone the weight of a phone or tablet. The foam arrived damaged, like it had been sitting in a damp warehouse for months. Avoid at all costs -- you'd have better luck propping your device against the wall.

Name: JJ
Review Text: Made of plastic w/ foam pads, uses a ratchet style adjustment. The plastic seems pretty durable and the foam that acts as a grip for the bottom as well as the device seems fine. I didn't have super high expectations for a $9 stand but I am pleasantly surprised by what I got. I tested it out on a phone (even though it was designed for something a bit larger) and it actually held my Note 4 in portrait mode quite well. I also tested w/ a 7 inch table and that too worked well. The nice thing about it is IMHO the ratchet style adjustments and the fact I can put into a pocket if I need/want to take it anywhere.

Name: T. Everett
Review Text: I use this stand to hold my iPad in place for Zoom meetings, and nothing more. That said, it does the job and at a reasonable price. If I wanted to type while using it...well, whoâ€™d want to type on a pad standing in front of him or her? Maybe with an outboard keyboard, but there arenâ€™t a lot of those and when I want to type or use any of many apps, I hold the Pad in my hands.When I first got the stand, I set it up cautiously, because the plastic legs take a certain amount of force to pull apart. But if they didnâ€™t, Iâ€™d be worried that they wouldnâ€™t hold.

Name: Jordan
Review Text: This is great cheap stand. It's simple, yet ingenuitive.  Itâ€™s versatile in the respect that it allows you use it on a variety of devices and that you are able to stand the devices up vertically, horizontally, and at many angles.  I have used it on my iPhone 6, iPhone 5, iPad, and Kindle with and without the cases on it. Itâ€™s really sturdy, portable, and easy to set up. I typically throw this in my luggage so I can watch movies on my trips. My only issue with this product is that the padding comes off the bottom really easily, but this wouldnâ€™t prevent me from buying this again. The padding coming off didnâ€™t seem to affect the performance of the stand and havenâ€™t scratched any surface that I am aware of yet.If you have any questions about this product, feel free to ask me as I personally rely heavily on other peopleâ€™s reviews for my Amazon purchases.This product was a personal purchase for myself at the normal retail price. I am reviewing it solely because to share my experience with other potential customers. I have received no compensation for my review nor do I have any relationship with the seller or manufacturer of this product.

Name: Clarence Threepwood
Review Title: Surprised at all the positive reviews!  Yes, it has some plusses (sort of), but there are decided problems!
Review Text: OK, first off, the plusses.  It sort of works as a stand.  It sorts of works somewhat better with smaller tablets-- e.g., the iPad Mini.  You can, sort of, make some adjustments of the legs and the back prop.  But, if that sounds way short of a ringing endorsement, that's because it is!Several problems with this stand.  As some of the more discerning reviewers have pointed out, it is unstable--at least it is if it is on a dining room table cloth.  Perhaps the underside grippy things help on an uncovered desk.  At it stands (or doesn't! :-)), it wobbles and can easily tip over.  I've tried it with both an iPad Air and an iPad Mini.  It works better for the smaller tablets, but switching between the two is a nuisance!  The feet need to be splayed out as far as they can go to get even a modicum of stability for the larger tablet, but then the mini tablets can't fit; they'll fall between the legs (portrait).Another big issue.  Lift your tablet and the darn stand often sticks to it!  It then falls to the ground, the table, wherever with a clatter.Another BIG problem... there is no felt covering on the top side of the feet where the tablet rests.  It has the felt on the front top side, but not the back!  THAT MEANS IT'S RIFE WITH SCRATCH POTENTIAL!  It needs a better design so that the entire area is covered.  You can see that on some of the clones (or, wait-- this is a clone)--those have the felt on the back and front.  I know that a different stand (a mini-plastic easel) scratched the edge of my Mini because the hard plastic dug into it.  So, felt covering is important.  On both this and that, one can cut out and put some sticky felt strips on to cover things, which generally solves the problem.  Not elegant, but it works pretty well.Amazingly, overall, this stand is *worse* than the $2.99 mini-adjustable easel stand we bought at Jo Ann Fabrics!  That stand has an easy to adjust back frame, which means it is easy to change the viewing angle--it smoothly goes to any angle you want.  In contrast, this stand does not work well.  Both the backing and the feet cannot be smoothly moved into another position-- instead, there are notches and you have move from one set gap to another.  When moving the feet, it even seems as if one is going to break a notch!Stability is another issue, especially if you simply want to move the stand and tablet over some.  Move the stand with the tablet and it's almost sure to fall over!  This morning, I even had grabbed the upright prop part with the iPad, when I moved it over.  "No problem", I naively thought.  All of a sudden, it fell over on its side!I'd return this to Amazon, but at its low price, it's not worth the time, hassle, mailing, or effort.

Name: Scott D
Review Title: Good Quality and Easy to Use with any Tablets Folds Flat
Review Text: We use this with an IPAD and also have a less expensive tablet for reading. This stand will adjust for any larger tablet and hold it into place. The great feature is that it has small ridges to keep the tablet in place and you can adjust your angle of view for reading. High-quality construction1. Universal Fit for Larger and smaller tablets2.Adjustable for the best reading angles3. High Quality stays in place during use4. Folds flat when not in use

Name: Tiffany
Review Text: Inexpensive and does exactly what it is supposed to do. I like how adjustable it is so I can angle my ipad any way I want it. Sometimes use it for my phone too although it doesn't work as well because the phone is too small for it. Been using it for more than a year and it still works. However, the foam on the bottom that is supposed to help stabilize it has fallen off/no longer sticks to the product but eh, it's expected since it's just a sticker

Name: cbb
Review Text: I can't rate its sturdiness yet, since I haven't had it very long; however, I really like its versatility.  It adjusts easily, and fits my Kindle Fire in its slightly bulky case, plus also adjusts down to hold my Samsung Galaxy S9 phone.  I like the variety of angle adjustments, too.  Closes up neatly and fairly small for portability. I've wanted something to support my Kindly vertically, since my case only does it horizontally, and this has done the trick.Will update on sturdiness at a later date.

Name: Joe R.
Review Text: Flimsy.  Will not support an Ipad Pro.  Each adjustment hurts the adjusting mechanisms.  Not made to be adjusted often or made to last.  Would have been a bargain at $3, but is a rip off for $12

Name: Bruce W.
Review Title: Great portable stand for a Kindle Fire HD 10
Review Text: Great stand for hands free reading while seated or otherwise occupied.  Has the necessary structure to handle the large Fire in portrait mode (so many stands only really work in landscape).  Very lightweight and collapses to almost nothing.  The only gripe I have is that the foam tape on the bottom that is supposed to keep the stand from slipping peeled off within a week of receipt.  The problem is that the feet are molded with cavities in the bottom to keep the weight down and the foam does not have much to stick to.  Solved that problem by filling the last few cavities with Bondo equivalent and then put small rubber bumpers on the bondo and at the top of the Y.  Even more stable now with the tripod contact.  Love it.  Hope it lasts forever.

Name: Tony R.Top Contributor: Cooking
Review Title: A Good Stand for Tablet Support
Review Text: I ordered this stand as there are times, particularly when I'm watching a video or reading, that I don't want to hold my Kindle and wanted something it could rest on.  This stand works fine, but there are a few elements that I think could improve it.  First, there are no clips or restraining bars to keep your table from tipping forward or slipping off the stand.  Certainly, if you simply put this stand on a flat surface then it's probably not an issue.  But I sometimes use it when in bed for reading, etc and the surface is not always flat.  Inevitably it falls forward or slips to the left or right.  There are slight grooves in the 'feet' where the tablet sits, but they aren't deep enough to securely hold the tablet.  A minor issue to be sure, but the stand would be improved if it had some additional restraints or locks.  Still, for the money a good buy.

Name: Amaramar
Review Text: This is a great stand. I use it for both and huge iPadPro (about 13" screen), and a standard sized iPad (about 10" screen).  It folds down really well into a smallish rectangular shape. It is maybe a little more bulky when folded than other stands, but is a really sturdy stand - so that's a good compromise. The flexibility of all the different positions is great.

Name: Norris G.
Review Text: This "AmazonBasics Portable Fold-Up Travel Stand", is really great for the generations of Ipads and Android Tablets, it holds them at different angles and best of all it won`t move when you tap your Ipad or Android Tablet, i tried it on my bed, desk, sofa, countertop and even on a clip board on my lap and i am very impressed with this travel stand. I have tried other products by "Amazon Basics" and have not been let down as of yet and that was my main reason for trying this. It seems to be made of good quality materials and constructed very well, it will last for years to come. It has a literally slip proof material on the bottom and on the easel like back holder and it is a quality piece of workmanship, it folds up and you can place it in your pocket, electronics carrying  bag or a lady`s purse, very convenient idea. I really love this and do recommend this product. Thanks

Name: Harmon
Review Title: Takes up too much table space
Review Text: This stand functions pretty well to hold my 10 inch iPad Pro, although I can't quite get an angle I like . YMMV. But my main gripe about it is that because of its design, it takes up too much table space as compared to other, smaller, stands. It occupies a six inch square on the table top, which might not sound like much but when you are doing something other than just having a cup of coffee, I find it hard to get it it acceptably positioned for reading.

Name: Kenny
Review Text: I was pretty impressed with the product when it arrived. It is pretty sturdy, though a bit stiff, especially the legs. I used it for 2 days without any issues with both my phone and an iPad. Today when I was trying to adjust it on the table, the self-adhesive anti-skid material on the bottom rolled and stuck to the table instead of the stand. After pulling it mostly off before realizing there was an issue. I've tried to stick it back on, but I don't think it will stick well. Sigh! I actually liked this.

Name: Erik Gordon Bainbridge
Review Text: A solid, basic, well-done product, like all AmazonBasics items I've purchased.  I mostly use it for my Samsung 8" tablet (with a thick Bobj rugged case), but it also works for my Moto G4 phone (also with a rugged case).  If you're looking for a tablet stand that will impress people with its appearance, this is the wrong one for you, but if you want a solid, inexpensive stand that does what it's supposed to, this one fits the bill.The one drawback, as many reviewers have noted, is that you can't charge the device while it's in the stand.  For me, it's not a problem.  It's not good for the battery to have it continually plugged in, so I charge mine at night and use it solely on battery during the day.

Name: FloridAmazon
Review Text: With the 9.7-inch iPad Pro I am finally able to make the transition to all-digital, and having a handy place to keep this iPad so it is always within easy reach is key to that transition. I bought one of these stands to keep in my briefcase and quickly realized I needed more. Now I have three -- one for my office and two for home. They are well worth the price. Folded up they are very portable, but they are quickly opened and can be universally adjusted. I'm watching more and more content online, so it's great to prop my iPad up on this stand and settle in to binge watch something on Amazon Prime Video.These stands are also great for charging your tablet. Just place the side with the charging port to the left or right and plug it in. Like all the Amazon Basics products I have purchased, they are well made and affordable. If you're looking for a way to comfortably view your tablet or phone, you can't go wrong with this product.

Name: NE Ohioan
Review Text: Looking for an easy to pack stand to use on an upcoming trip. Wanted something that was easy to fold up but looked study enough to use. This little stand came in a very small box but when opened up, supports my iPad quite well. Already have used it to hold my iPad with a movie going while I was cleaning. I really like the small size and how nicely it folds up. Thinking about getting another one, just in case I misplace this (loose it while cleaning). Would definitely recomment this little stand.

Name: R. Ybarra
Review Title: Best Tablet Stand for the Price
Review Text: This has been one of the better tablet stands I've found.  It works well for iPad, iPad Mini and Galaxy Tab.  It even does a decent job on the LG3 and can be used on an iPhone 6 in a pinch.  It folds compactly and is very adjustable.  Once in position, the arms are tight enough that they will not shift.  I have had it about 18 months now and it is holding up well.  The sole issue I've had with this stand is that, depending on tablet placement, there is not enough clearance in the feet for the charging cable to plug in without putting undo strain on the cable.  This is a rather minor point, however.  You also need to make sure that you spread the feet wide enough for your tablet model to give sturdy support.Yes, there are some better stands available, however they cost several times the price of this one and they tend to be more artistic than functional.  As I say in the title, this stand provides the best use for the price - something I've come to expect from Amazon Basics.  Since everyone in the family is now fighting over who gets to use this one, I will be buying a couple more.

Name: Pilar G. Vargas
Review Title: Great tablet for airplanes and kitchens
Review Text: I bought this for a long flight with my 7and 5 year old. California to Italy. I loaded up the iPad with movies and games. This tablet holder was amazing the adjustments could fit any tablet, and the grip on the base insured it stayed in place on the tray table, even during some pretty strong turbulence. Now I'm back home and I use it in the kitchen and in my garage when I'm building something. Works great. Feels pretty durable too. Folds up nicely. Compact would be a good way of describing it.

Name: Technosorcerer
Review Title: Not just a one night stand!
Review Text: Using this with my kindle fire 10. It holds it secure with kindle cover on it. It fold up to a size looks like could fit in a pocket well.Folded it's about the size of a hair brush handle maybe 1 to 2 inches longer. First time opening legs thought Iight break it, but it didn't break and after it opens with less effort. I mention this cause no instructions mention a release catch. Just a stiff movement first time. Think it's pretty much all plastic, might not set off metal detectors, unless the screws set something off.

Name: Dan The Driver
Review Text: I have an old Samsung Tab E I use with my stereo system. Several of the apps I use don't work in landscape so I wanted a mount to hold the tablet in portrait. This looked perfect but it is VERY wobbly and the arm doesn't sit flush against the back of the tablet making it even more unstable. I don't trust it at all and it will just go in the mistakes pile.It is a universal mount so it is not designed for any device in particular and it clearly doesn't work for my needs!

Name: Kindle Customer
Review Text: bed-bound parent needed a stable kickstand for her tablet. liked it so much, i bought 3 more.PROS: lightweight. strong. easy to set tablet or phone securely. won't collapse on its own. folds into a tiny little thing so super simple to store, even in your pocket. i use it for my chromebook! son uses for his phone, husband uses for his tablet. surprisingly inexpensive.CONS: this is a first for me; NONE. not a single bad thing to say. VERY happy i bought.

Name: Dawn
Review Title: i think i have four of these now
Review Text: I keep buying ones to live in each room and i just carry my tablet from room to room. I got tired of carrying the stand around and i don't like the cases with built in stands so this is my solution. theyre cheap enough i just have one  in each room... just there ready to go for me. i use the tablet for different functions in different rooms but pretty much use it for everything all day long so the stands are great. theyre very sturdy and you just sit the tablet on it nbd.

Name: Brigandier
Review Title: The stand itself is nice, but it does not fit the kindle fire ...
Review Text: I bought this to hold the kindle fire HD 8 (version 6) upright for games that did not work horizontally.  The stand itself is nice, but it does not fit the kindle fire HD well while standing up as in the picture.  I have to close the legs one notch each and I have very minor tilt / uneven-ness.  It may not bother you, but it bothers me a little bit.  For anything bigger than a kindle fire this would probably work just fine.

Name: Katherine E. Shelby
Review Text: I bought this stand 2 1/2 years ago and it just broke today. I'm not sure how long they're supposed to last, but I was hoping for longer than this. I was folding it up after lunch, and the top section came apart. There's a spring and a nut and something else I couldn't find - under my work desk - that holds it together. If I knew what the something else was, I'd try to fix it. If you don't mind spending $10 every few years (although it was only $8.99 two years ago), then this is a great stand. If you're like me and don't have a lot of extra money, I'd look for something sturdier even if it means spending a little extra.

Name: Mum2SissynBub
Review Title: Finally a truly adjustable, affordable and adaptable stand. At the price its well worth a try. You will not regret it.
Review Text: I Love this stand! I use my Kindle sort of like a laptop. I had made up a stand myself but it kept falling over caused damage to my other kindle before this one. I happened upon the advertisment and decided with the price that affordable why not give it a go? I honestly did not think that it would be anything that usefull. Possibly clunky and in the way. But no the 3 "legs" are all ajustable even the one supporting the back. I can see it would accomidate ANY device even phones. I have a 10 inch screen and it fit perfectly. Even with it in a large bulky keyboard case. They have little grooves that have a rubbery non skip foam applied and also on the bottom of the legs.On a hard surface like a table or counter this is not going to move or shift. I love this and just wish I had found it sooner.I will definately be buying this for any and all devices I get in the future.

Name: Linda J. Doffek
Review Title: I should have bought this stand ages ago!
Review Text: I wish I would have bought this sooner.  It's great for holding my Fire tablet.  I use it on my bedside table mostly and it prevents me from dropping it out of my hand if I nod off!  I can't tell you how many times my Fire tablet hit the floor!  Thank goodness it's still working fine.  Really well made and sturdy, and very adjustable.

Name: N. HylandTop Contributor: Photography
Review Title: Forget this for vertical use with iPad
Review Text: - Not heavy enough. Needs more weight in bottom for stability.- Slot on base legs for iPad not wide enough for thin cover folded back.- Does not sit high enough for placing iPad vertical. Like for reading news on table, reading recipes or next to stereo for streaming music â€” tight spaces where vertical is needed with power/charging or WITH lightning for power and/or DAC. So you have to invert it and have cables at top. Awkward.

Name: Sherry Y.
Review Text: Ok, so I admit, I am a sucker for gadgets....especially gadgets for my devices...my pocket pc's, IPad, my Nintendos(ds, dsi, 3ds and dsxl) and now my newest addition to my device family: my Amazon Kindle Touch!I have been purchasing all the covers and stands that look like they will work better than the last one, and I just received this stand.Oh my goodness, this stand is AMAZING!!!! It moves in so many positions, but is sturdy enough to hold my devices in any position I need them in. I'm very pleased to see all the different combinations and variations of positions this stand has!The back of the stand doesn't hook to my device, however it has a nice rubber texture to keep the device from slipping. But here's the fun part:  I also just received the Marware Kindle touch cover today that has a place to put my hand through the flap(elastic strap) when I fold it backward (see my next review) and I put that strap Over the back of the stand and Yippee!! I have just the perfect combo of products that totally work for me!  No matter what position, my kindle is secure in a hands free position.I have reviewed other gadgets that also work, but so far, this is my very favorite combo for my Kindle Touch.Oh, and of all the book lights I've tried, RocketFish is the very lightest and brightest(very small in comparison to mighty bright, but just as bright with brightness switch.)

Name: JB
Review Title: Cannot plug iPad in and hold vertical at the same time
Review Text: Product seems fine but the base isn't tall enough to keep the iPad plugged in and upright while charging.  To keep it on the stand while charging you have to turn it sideways.  So it depends on your purpose - this detail doesn't matter if you just use it as a travel stand which I think most people do.  I wanted a desk stand so I could use an old iPad like a photo display or to watch stock tickers, and for those purposes I'd rather just keep it plugged in.  Otherwise it seems pretty good.

Name: flapjackjoe
Review Text: Short and simple. Like many of the other reviews say, it's honestly the best tablet stand I've had. I've had a few, and they all fall short. This one is extremely versatile, folds into almost any shape. I didn't think this would actually work for my cell phone - I thought it would be too wide. But I was able to get it into the shape I needed to work with my LGG8. I only bought one for my home office, but will be buying a few more for the office, other rooms, and even as gifts. A great buy!

Name: Chris
Review Text: With remote learning in full effect and a kindergartener having to learn via a tablet, I had to find some sort of stand... as we'd been rigging random household items to hold it up prior.I was skeptical ordering this...and even more skeptical when it arrived.  Cheap plastic thing.  Total rip off.First impressions, this time, were wrong.  In fact, I'd have to say that my expectations with AmazonBasics items have always been low...but always exceeded.This thing holds up to a less than gentle 5-year old, it's super adaptable to any angle, and even though it's really lightweight, it never gets top heavy to the point that it topples over.  Stability on a flat surface is legit.While we don't use it anywhere but his desktop work space and never actually move it around...if I were a tablet-on-the-go kinda guy, I'd find it's ability to fold down to a really small size to be a great feature.

Name: MCN
Review Text: I wanted a tablet stand so I could keep my tablet beside my desktop while I worked. I did not want a unit that took up lots of space.  I read the reviews and decided to try this adjustable stand.  First of all, when I am not using the stand, it folds up very small and barely takes up any space.  Second, I can adjust it many ways to hold my tablet upright, sideways, leaning back further, etc.  It is a pretty amazing design - like a little transformer toy - and very sturdy.

Name: John H. Meyer
Review Text: This is a ridiculously simple design that works on every level:It is lightweight.It folds into almost nothing.It can be configured to hold your tablet at different angles and orientations.It doesn't skid.Even though it doesn't have clips, the rubber "grips" the tablet amazingly well.I have a Fire HD 10 Tablet (10.1" 1080p full HD display, 32 GB), and this is the perfect stand for it.

Name: I am a Demon hunter
Review Text: When I bought this I remember someone had said why would you waste your money on this dinky cheapy crap. Well, it turns out its the best dinky cheapy crap I've ever bought. First of all, it's cheap but not cheaply made. You can drop it all day long and nothing will happen to it. We use it daily and it folds up easily into a purse so we can take it to a restaurant so that the kids can watch their ipads while we eat. If you spill something on it- not problem. You can rinse it under a faucet. An absoulte fantastic device. Highly recommend it!

Name: PJ
Review Text: I got this stand for my 11in iPad Pro and it works... okay. I mainly got it to use on carpet and itâ€™s not stable on that type of surface. I am a heavy handed person and it was easy for me to tilt my iPad over while typing, writing, or drawing. On a table it works great. Still kinda easy to tip over but it was harder to do so. It serves its purpose but itâ€™s my fault for having expensive expectations for a cheaper product therefore I wonâ€™t give a bad rating.

Name: Kindle Customer
Review Text: This product is so flimsy and small that it would not be sturdy enough to hold my cell phone let alone one of my Kindles.Very disappointed.

Name: James JamesonTop Contributor: Photography
Review Text: Not a whole lot to say about this stand. It's simple and cheap. It allows you to pretty much angle your tablet anyway you want it, while it's sitting on a flat surface. It's cheap plastic and cheaply built, but it doesn't really matter unless your trekking up to the mountains, or need to check your email during an earthquake or hurricane.It's fine sitting on a table or desk, and can be folded up easily and thrown in your bag. It doesn't need to be made out of titanium. That being said, it is plastic. I wouldn't place in the bottom of a bag filled with heavy things on top it. But that should be obvious. It's just right for the price.

Name: Job S Tadoo
Review Text: Got this for my Kindle Paperwhite. It has a great texture and look. The Kindle snaps in very nicely. The hinge works well on opening and closing so it feels like a unit either end - not wiggly or the like. I use it in a little reading stand and the cloth texture means it stays in place. It protects the Kindle too - the cloth cover is over a hard case. It adds very little weight, and I actually like this as it feels more like a book. I'm very happy with it.

Name: Sourcehound
Review Title: Effective but Bulkier than the Tablets It Holds
